contextId.information: "Have you thought about my servant Job?" Here God is beginning to talk with Satan about Job. AT: "Consider my servant Job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you considered my servant Job?

contextId.information: "Does Job respect God for no reason?" Satan responds to God by presenting and answering his own question. He says that Job obeys God only because God blesses him. AT: "Job has a reason for obeying God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Does Job fear God without reason?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question actually makes a statement.Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:01:06|1:8]]. AT: "Consider my servant Job." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]).
contextId.quote: Have you considered my servant Job?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question represents a statement. AT: "You should not still be holding fast to your integrity." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you still hold fast to your integrity?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question represents a statement. AT: "We should certainly receive the bad from God as well as the good." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should we receive the good from God and not receive the bad?

contextId.information: "Why did I not die at birth?" Job poses this question in order to curse the day of his birth and to express his anguish. AT: "I wish I had died the day I was born" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why did I not die when I came out from the womb?

contextId.information: This perhaps refers to the lap of Job's mother. His mother's knees are spoken of as if they were people who could welcome a newborn baby. AT: "I wish there had been no lap to receive me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Why did her knees welcome me?

contextId.information: Eliphaz asks this question in order to make a statement. AT: "you will surely be impatient." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: will you be impatient?

contextId.information: Eliphaz uses this question to prompt Job to search his life for sin (and God's righteous judgment) as the cause of his loss. AT: "No one has ever perished when innocent." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: who has ever perished when innocent?

contextId.information: Eliphaz poses this question so that Job will consider, "Do I regard myself as more righteous than God?" or "Am I justified before God?" AT: "A mortal man cannot be more righteous than God" or "A mortal man cannot be righteous before God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can a mortal man be more righteous than God?

contextId.information: "Do I say wicked things?" Job uses this question to rebuke his friends and to emphasize that he is not wicked. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "I do not say wicked things." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is there evil on my tongue?

contextId.information: Job asks this question to emphasize that he wonders why God pays attention to people. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "Tell me what man is that ... every moment." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What is man that ... every moment?

contextId.information: Zophar is asking a question in the negative to emphasize that Job's words must be challenged. AT: "We must answer all of these words!" or "Someone should respond to all these words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should not such a multitude of words be answered?

contextId.information: Zophar uses this question to rebuke Job. AT: "Just because you have spoken many words, this does not mean that others must keep silent." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should your boasting make others remain silent?

contextId.information: Job used this question to express a truth that should be obvious to his listeners. It can be expressed as a statement. AT: "Indeed, there is no one who does not know such things as these" or "Indeed, everyone knows these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Indeed, who does not know such things as these?

contextId.information: Job uses these two questions to rebuke his friends for speaking unrighteously.  AT: "You think that you are speaking for God, but you are speaking unrighteously. You are speaking deceitfully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
contextId.quote: Will you speak unrighteously ... deceitfully for him?

contextId.information: Showing kindness to God represents helping God or defending God against Job's complaints. Job uses these questions to rebuke his friends for thinking that they can defend God.  AT: "You think that you can defend God. You think that you can argue for God like attorneys in court" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
contextId.quote: Would you really ... as attorneys for God?

contextId.information: Here "searches you out" is a metaphor meaning "examine you." Job uses this question to warn his friends that if God were to examine them, he would say that what they are doing is wrong. AT: "If God were to examine you, it would not be good for you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Would it really be good for you when he searches you out

contextId.information: Job asks this question to complain about how God is treating him. He probably hopes for an answer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you hide ... like your enemy?

contextId.information: Job uses these questions to tell God that since Job is so insignificant and weak, it is useless to persecute him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Will you persecute ... pursue dry stubble?

contextId.information: Job implies that he does not want God to pay so much attention to him. AT: "You do not look at any of these" or "You do not pay so much attention to these. Please do not pay so much attention to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you look at any of these?

contextId.information: Job uses this question to persuade God to apply what he knows about unclean things to Job. AT: "No one can bring something clean out of something unclean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who can bring something clean out of something unclean? No one

contextId.information: The implicit answer here is "no." This rhetorical question can be written as a statement. AT: "You are not the first man that was born" [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are you the first man that was born?

contextId.information: The implicit answer here is "no." This rhetorical question can be written as a statement. AT: "You have not heard the secret knowledge of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you heard the secret knowledge of God?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question is asked to emphasize that a man cannot be completely "clean." This can be written as a statement. AT: "A man, he cannot be completely clean." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What is man that he should be clean?

contextId.information: Job uses this rhetorical question to express that he wishes that they would stop speaking useless words. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "How I wish your useless words would end!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will useless words ever have an end?

contextId.information: The implicit answer is "no." This question can be written as a statement. AT: "Hope will not go down with me ... dust." or "I will no longer hope when I go down ... dust." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will hope go down with me ... dust?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question means that Job has been talking for too long. This may be written as a statement. AT: "Stop talking!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: When will you stop your talk?

contextId.information: Bildad uses this rhetorical question to emphasize to Job that he should not consider to be dumb. He speaks of them being consider dumb by calling them "beasts." This question can be written as a statement. AT: "You should not think that we are like beasts." or "You should not think that we are dumb like animals." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why are we regarded as beasts

contextId.information: This is an exclamation. Possible meanings are 1) that they will certainly persecute Job or 2) that they will persecute him severely. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How we will persecute him!

contextId.information: Zophar uses a question to cause Job to think deeply about what he will now say. AT: "Surely you know what has been true since the ancient times ...  for a moment." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know this fact from ancient times ... for a moment?

contextId.information: Job uses this second question to emphasize that it seems to him that God does not punish the wicked very often. AT: "It is not often ... in his anger." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: How often does it happen ... in his anger?

contextId.information: Job uses this question to contradict his friends' belief that the wicked are always judged. AT: "No one condemns the wicked man to his face." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who will condemn the wicked man's way to his face?

contextId.information: Eliphaz uses this question to suggest that God see Job's sin and will judge him. AT: "God is in the heights of heaven and sees everything that happens on earth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Is not God in the heights of heaven?

contextId.information: Job uses this question to emphasize that God is unique. AT: "But there is no one like him, and nobody can make him change his mind." or "But he alone is God, and no one can influence him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: But he is one of a kind, who can turn him back?

contextId.information: Job uses this question to express his frustration that God has not judged evil. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I do not understand why God does not set a time when he will judge wicked people." or "The Almighty should set a time when he will judge wicked people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Why are times for judging wicked people not set by the Almighty?

contextId.information: Bildad uses this question to express how great God is. The implicit answer is "no." This refers to the armies of God's angels. AT: "There is no end to the number of angels in his army." or "His armies are so big that no one can count them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Is there any end to the number of his armies?

contextId.information: Job uses this question to say that such a man has no hope. AT: "There is no hope for the godless when God ... takes away his soul." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: For what is the hope of a godless man when ... when God takes away his life?

contextId.information: Job uses this question to mock the weakness of those men. AT: "The strength of their fathers' hands could not have helped me ... perished." or "(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Indeed, the strength of their fathers' hands, how could it have helped me ... perished?

contextId.information: Job uses these questions to remind God of how Job had done good to others. A: "You know that I wept ... trouble, and I grieved ... man!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Did not I weep ... trouble? Did I not grieve ... man?

contextId.information: Elihu uses this question to emphaize that Job should not struggle against God. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "You should not struggle against God" or "You should not try to argue with God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Why do you struggle against him?

contextId.information: Elihu uses this rhetorical question to scold Job. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "There is no one else like Job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What man is like Job

contextId.information: The implicit answer to this rhetorical question is "no." This question implies that God could not rule the world if he hated justice. This can be written as a statement. AT: "One who hate justice cannot govern the world." or "God could certainly never hate was is right and still rule the world." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Can one who hates justice govern?

contextId.information: Elihu uses this rhetorical question to teach Job. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "No one can criticize God if he decides to remain silent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: When he stays silent, who can condemn him?

contextId.information: "Since you dislike what God does, do you think that God should punish this person's sin?" Elihu uses this rhetorical question to emphasize that he should not think that God will not punish this man. This can be written as a statement. AT: "Even though you do not like what God does, surely even you do not think that God will punish this person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you think that God will punish that person's sin, since you dislike what God does?

contextId.information: Elihu uses questions to challenge Job. AT: "You must think you are right ... 'My right before God.'" or "It is not just ... 'My right before God.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you think this is just ... 'My right before God'?

contextId.information: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job's sins cannot actually do anything to God. AT: "If you have sinned, do have not done any hard to God." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: If you have sinned, what harm do you do to God?

contextId.information: Elihu asks these questions to emphasize that money and power will not be able to help Job if he acts unjustly. AT: "Your wealth cannot benefit you ... all the force of your strength cannot help you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can your wealth benefit you ... can all the force of your strength help you?

contextId.information: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job cannot do this. AT: "You cannot spread out the sky ... a mirror of cast metal." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can you spread out the sky ... a mirror of cast metal?

contextId.information: Elihu asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one can do this. AT: "I cannot have someone tell him that I wish to speak with him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should he be told that I wish to speak with him?

contextId.information: This can be translated as a statement. AT: "Tell me who determined its dimensions, if you know" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who determined its dimensions? Tell me, if you know

contextId.information: This can be translated as a statement. AT: "Tell me who shut up the sea with doors ... and thick darkness its swaddling bands." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who shut up the sea with doors ... and thick darkness its swaddling bands?

contextId.information: These questions expect negative answers. They can be expressed as statements. AT: "You have not gone to the sources of the waters of the sea, or walked in the lowest parts of the deep. The gates of death have not been revealed to you, and you have not seen the gates of the shadow of death. You do not understand the earth in its expanse." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you gone ... in its expanse?

contextId.information: These can be translated as statements. AT: "Tell me if you can fasten chains on the Pleiades, or undo the cords of Orion. Tell me if you can lead the constellations to appear at their proper times, or guide the Bear with its children. Tell me if you know the regulations of the sky, or whether you could set in place the sky's rule over the earth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can you fasten chains ... over the earth?

contextId.information: These can be translated as statements. AT: "Tell me if you can raise your voice up to the clouds, so that an abundance of rainwater may cover you. Tell me if you can send out bolts of lightning that they may go out, that they say to you, 'Here we are!'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can you raise ... 'Here we are'?

contextId.information: These questions can be translated as statements. AT: "Tell me who has put wisdom in the clouds and given understanding to the mists. Tell me who can number the clouds by his skill. Tell me who can pour out the water skins of the sky when the dust runs into a hard mass and the clods of earth clump tightly together." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who has put wisdom ... tightly together?

contextId.information: This can be translated as a statement. AT: "You cannot count the months that they are pregnant." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can you count the months that they gestate?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses two questions to emphasize that he greater than Job because Yahweh takes care of the wild donkeys and Job does not. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who let ... the salt land?

contextId.information: This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You cannot control the wild ox with a rope in order to plow furrows in your fields." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: With a rope, can you control the wild ox to plow the furrows?

contextId.information: These two clauses basically mean the same thing. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You will not be able to depend on him ... grain for your threshing floor." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Will you depend on him ... grain for your threshing floor?

contextId.information: This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You are not able to make him jump like a locust." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you ever made him jump like a locust?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to prove that Job is not as great as Yahweh. The implicit answer to this question is "no." AT: "It is not by your wisdom ... for the south." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is it by your wisdom ... for the south?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to prove that Job is not powerful enough to command the eagles. The implicit answer to this question is "no." AT: "You are not able to command the eagle to mount up and build his nest in high places." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is it at your orders ... nest in high places?

contextId.information: Yahweh is rebuking Job. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "No one who wants to criticize me should try to argue with me, for I am Almighty God." or "You, a person, want to criticize me, Almighty God, but you should not try to correct me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should anyone who wishes to criticize try to correct the Almighty?

contextId.information: Job uses this question to apologize for questioning God. AT: "I cannot answer you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how can I answer you

contextId.information: The word "actually" indicates that Yahweh is surprised that Job would say that Yahweh is unjust and that Job should make sure that he really wants to say that. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "I am surprised that you are saying I am unjust." or "You should be sure that you want to say that I am unjust, because that is what you are saying." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will you actually say that I am unjust?

contextId.information: This can be translated as a statement. AT: "You know that no one can capture him with a hook or pierce his nose through with a snare" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can anyone capture him with a hook ... snare?

contextId.information: This can be translated as a statement. AT: "You know that you cannot draw out Leviathan with a fishhook". (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Can you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook?

contextId.information: This can be translated as a statement. AT: "You know that he will not make pleas to you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will he make many pleas to you?

contextId.information: This can be translated as a statement. AT: "No one can strip off his outer clothing." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who can strip off his outer covering?

contextId.information: Most modern versions agree that Job is loosely quoting God's own words from [[:en:bible:notes:job:38:01|38:2]]. Translators may therefore decide, as does the UDB, to make it clear that God asked this question of Job and that Job is now remembering it. AT: "You said to me, 'Who is this who has no knowledge, but who dares to hide my plans from people?'" Or, "You said to me, 'You have no knowledge; you should not tell lies about my plans.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Who is this who without knowledge conceals plans?
